title: A Museum in Baghdad, RSC Swan, review: the admirable but convoluted tale of a great pioneer
text: To read about the life and times of Gertrude Bell is to face the prospect of your jaw dropping to the floor and needing reconstructive surgery. Born (in 1868) in Durham to manufacturing wealth and progressive-minded privilege, she made the most of every opportunity, her personality forceful, restless, inquisitive. In 1888, she became the first woman to gain first-class honours in Modern History at Oxford and then set off to see the world, going round it twice, founding Iraq (!) and engaging in the kind of exploration and escapades one associates with TE Lawrence. After her death in 1926, King Faisal (of Iraq) paid tribute and said “She could play a man’s part in the action… She ventured alone...
description: To read about the life and times of Gertrude Bell is to face the prospect of your jaw dropping to the floor and needing reconstructive surgery.
